Influence of LOR on the histopathological and immunohistochemical studies in mouse corneas 14 days after UV irradiation. The typical histologic findings of cornea stained with hematoxylin and eosin (A, B) are shown. A: The cornea in the saline-treated group shows marked inflammation, obvious edema, profound neovascularization, and significant hypercellularity in the stroma. B: The cornea in the LOR-treated group exhibits only scattered inflammatory cells, mild stromal swelling, and less neovascularization. Corneal tissues (C-F) were analyzed by immunohistochemistry to determine the expression of NF-B. Immunohistochemical staining with an antibody against activated NF-B was performed to detect the expression of NF-B. Sections incubated without a primary antibody served as negative controls. All tissue sections were counterstained with hematoxylin. These samples were representative of all corneas examined. Brown staining indicates activated NF-B. C,D: The cornea in the mock-infected group and the cornea in LOR alone group show that NF-B activity is only observed very faintly in the base cells of epithelium (arrowheads). E: Recurrence induced wide spread positive staining of NF-B, which was most robust in the stroma (arrows) of the saline-treated group. F: Scant immunoreactivity of NF-B was observed in the stroma of the LOR-treated group (arrows). Original magnifications, 400X.

The sample appears to be from a gastrointestinal organ, possibly the colon, based on the presence of epithelium, a thick layer, and muscularis propria.
Sebaceous carcinoma will have a few vessels but not extravasated red blood cells.
Presence of melanin in the cells.
Clusters of spores are present in certain areas of the sample.
Clear cells and a network of vessels are present.
The narrator is observing a true intraepidermal super basilar clefting or vesicle with villi and separation of keratinocytes. No evidence of herpes is present.
The formation does not look like xanthoma or xanthoma asthma.
Description of a pulsatile rapidly growing solitary bluish red lesion.
Possible apricot glands are present but difficult to see due to reactive change from inflammation.
The architecture of the glands is disturbed, which is a clue to the cause of the ulceration and granulation tissue.
The tumor is a relatively early stage luminal A tumor with a good prognosis, tends to be hormone positive and HER2 negative.
Immunohistochemical workup is being done to determine the type of tumor.
The diagnosis is mucinous carcinoma, which is a separate category in the WHO system for breast tumors.
Absence of perpendicular appearing vessels to the surface and presence of a stromal element are also noted.

The glands in the tissue are not normally structured and are somewhat branched and disturbed, which is a clue to the ulceration and granulation tissue. This appearance is characteristic of solitary rectal ulcer syndrome, which is caused by prolapse-related phenomenon.
The proliferation is getting close to the fatty tissues of the chest wall.
Presence of gastric antral type mucosa high in the esophagus, which is unusual and may indicate Barrett’s type of metaplasia with gastric antral type metaplasia and intestinal metaplasia.
Estrogen receptor staining shows a similar pattern with stronger staining in one area.
Possible consideration of an eosinophilic variant of clear cell carcinoma with apical nuclei, but high grade epithelial nuclear atypia should be present.
Disturbed gland architecture causing ulceration and granulation tissue.
Residual follicular differentiation and nuclear clearing with orphan anti-type appearance seen in some areas.
Eosinophilic and clear cell metaplasia may raise concern for hyperplasia and require follow-up.

The tumor is malignant but not ultra high grade or in the category of a high grade serious or poorly differentiated highly aggressive tumor. There can be endometrial variants of those tumors that can be difficult to determine.
Disturbed gland architecture causing ulceration and granulation tissue.
Spiradenoma and cylindroma are closely related and have different characteristics such as cell color, pattern, and inflammation.
PRP (pityriasis rubra pilaris) presents with checkerboard para-keratosis but no nudes or neutrophils.
Possibility that the cells may be melanocytes instead of lymphocytes.
Papillary renal cell carcinoma is associated with Reeds syndrome, which presents with multiple cutaneous leiomyomas, uterine leiomyomas, and papillary renal cell carcinoma.
Ortho and pericaritis may be relevant to the patient and their families.
Papillary fronds are seen in the neoplasm.

The narrator is concerned about neuroendocrine mucin producing carcinoma of the eyelid, which starts as a hidrocystoma and ends as mucinous carcinoma, with a cyst adenoma appearance along the way. Synaptophysin positivity is a hint. The tumor is likely malignant if it is on the eyelid.
Cylindroma has a jigsaw puzzle pattern and is not inflamed, while spiradenoma is peppered with lymphocytes.
Spiroadenocarcinoma is a type of adnexal carcinoma that can arise from a pre-existing adnexal neoplasm.
Description of a white, shaggy or hairy appearance on the tongue with bilateral and vertical lines, consistent with a clinical diagnosis.
Irregular glands with distorted appearance are a feature of malignancy.
Irregular, angulated glands with central lumina are present and infiltrating into connective and fatty tissue.
Nuclei are relatively rounded and uniform in benign tissue.
Obliterative phlebitis is a key feature, which can be identified with an elastic stain.
The appearance of subcapsular fibrosis in IgG4 related disease is similar to that seen in other areas of the pancreas, with dense collagen, inflamed stroma, and eosinophils.
The ducts of the parietal gland are referred to as striated ducts.
Description of the hepatic acinus, which is formed by two central veins and two portal triads, and consists of the terminal branches of the portal venules and the hepatic arterioles.
The ducts of the pancreas are not striated.
Portal lobule and hepatic acinus are being discussed.
Description of the hepatic acinus, which is formed by two central veins and two portal triads, and consists of the terminal branches of the portal venules and the hepatic arterioles.
The gallbladder contains numerous rugae with simple columnar epithelium that contains microvilli for fluid absorption.
Description of the sublingual glands, which are small paired salivary glands located on the floor of the mouth and account for only 5% of the total salivary volume.
Low-grade dedifferentiation can occasionally follow a heterologous elements type of pattern with some smooth muscle, cartilage, and bone.
Histopathological description of round cell sarcoma with small blue cells, scant cytoplasm, and hyperchromatic nuclei.
The cells show vacuolization and pronounced nuclear pleomorphism, suggesting an epithelial tumor.
Presence of necrosis and pleomorphism with lobulation suggests possibility of an epithelial tumor.
Giant cells are present, with bland nuclei and stromal cell nuclei similar to those of the tumor.
The tumor has a low-grade, more solid-appearing lesion, which can be an indication of low-grade dedifferentiation.
The next case may be confusing.
Histopathological description of a possible atypical lipomatous tumor with scattered atypical spindle cells within the fibrous matrix and bands between lobulated fatty tissue.
Medullary rays collect the filtrate from the cortical labyrinths and carry it down into the medullary region.
Explanation of the glomerular filtration barrier and movement of substances from the capillary lumen out into the urinary space or the Bowman’s space.
The nucleus seen in the capillary loop belongs to the endothelium.
Aldosterone causes sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules, leading to water reabsorption and increased blood volume and pressure.
Juxtaglomerular apparatus is composed of dense cells of the distal convoluted tubule.
Minor calyx is the first instance of having urinary epithelium.
Proximal convoluted tubules reabsorb most of the filtrate, including glucose, amino acids, electrolytes, and water.
Wiped out ischemic zones may indicate calciphylaxis, invasive fungus, or coagulopathy and require urgent attention.
Tumor cells can lose glandular differentiation in moderately differentiated tumors.
Dense connective tissue is more likely to be regular, while loose connective tissue is more likely to have fibers going in multiple directions.
The tissue being observed is areolar connective tissue, which appears pink and fibrillar due to collagen fibers.
The collagen fibers have a wavy pattern and are not uniform.
Liver is overloaded with fat, possibly up to 80-90% of its weight.
Presence of a scar in the biopsy that is not diffuse or homogeneous.
Pars nervosa does not contain any secretory cells.
Typical microscopic neutrophilic infiltrate in acute pyelonephritis localized in tubules.
Abscess formation may also be present.
The diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma, limited to the mucosa and not infiltrating.

Pathological microphotographs of the right adrenal composite pheochromocytoma with ganglioneuroblastoma. Different sections at the same position of the tumor were stained with Hematoxylin and Eosin staining (A) and for chromogranin A (B) and S-100 protein (C). The upper and lower halves of panels A to C represent the ganglioneuroblastoma and pheochromocytoma components of the tumor, respectively. In panel D, the GNBL component comprised a mixture of ganglion-like cells in a neurofibrillary background with no primitive neuroblastic foci, presenting with a characteristic morphology of GNBL-intermixed according to the international neuroblastoma pathology classification (original magnification 100× for A, B, and C, 200× for D).

Histopathological examination shows that the tumor comprises a main small cell carcinoma component (a) and a smaller squamous cell carcinoma component (b). Immunohistochemically, tumor cells of the small cell carcinoma component show positive staining for CD56 (c) but negative staining for CK5/6 (d). By contrast, cells of squamous cell carcinoma component were positive for CK5/6 (d) but negative for CD56 (c).
